slides.content:
# Structured Query Language

The standard language for relational database management systems (RDBMS).

Use it to store, retrieve, update, and manage data.

slides.title: Tables
slides.content:
# Rows & Columns üìä

Data is stored in **Tables**.

A table works like a spreadsheet.

- **Row (Record):** A single entry.
- **Column (Field):** A specific piece of data (e.g., Name, Age).

slides.quizQuestion: Which SQL statement is used to remove data from a database?

slides.title: UPDATE
slides.content:
# Modifying Data ‚úèÔ∏è

Change existing rows.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
UPDATE users 
SET email = 'new@example.com' 
WHERE id = 1;
FULL_CODE_END -->

‚ö†Ô∏è Always use a WHERE clause or you'll update EVERY row!

slides.title: DELETE
slides.content:
# Removing Data üóëÔ∏è

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
DELETE FROM users WHERE id = 1;
FULL_CODE_END -->

Again, don't forget the WHERE clause!

slides.title: ORDER BY
LIMIT
slides.content:
# Pagination üìÑ

Limit the number of results returned.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
SELECT * FROM users LIMIT 10;
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: DISTINCT
slides.content:
# Unique Values ü¶Ñ

Remove duplicates from the result set.

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
SELECT DISTINCT country FROM users;
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: SQL Basics üî§

Universal language.

- **SELECT:** Read.
- **INSERT:** Create.
- **UPDATE:** Modify.
- **DELETE:** Remove.
- **WHERE:** Filter.
